CALISTA WILL OFFER ITS SERVICES TO IMPROVE RECRUITMENT, MARKETING, AND RETENTION OF KEY YUKON DELTA REFUGE
POSITIONS. THE PRIMARY POSITIONS BEING TARGETED IN THIS PROPOSAL IS THE REFUGE INFORMATION TECHNICIAN (RIT). CALISTA WILL RECRUIT, HIRE, ONBOARD, AND OUTSOURCE THE RIT TO THE YUKON DELTA REFUGE TO PERFORM TASKS ASSIGNED BY THE US FWS.

TO PROVIDE A FRAMEWORK FOR INCREASING AWARENESS OF AND PARTICIPATION IN THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S MISSION, PROGRAMS AND EVENTS DURING PHI BETA SIGMA FRATERNITY S BIENNIAL CONFERENCE IN HOUSTON, TEXAS. FOCUSED EFFORTS WILL RAISE AWARENESS OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, AS WELL AS CAREER AND INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES.

A VARIETY OF PROJECTS HAVE BEEN SELECTED FOR THIS PROGRAM FUNDING WHICH IS WELL BALANCED BETWEENCOMMUNITY-BASED ECOLOGICAL MONITORING AND WEIR PROJECTS TO ASSESS AND QUANTIFY SALMON RETURNS AND RESILIENCE PLANNING THROUGH FOOD SECURITY EVALUATION TO EVALUATE SUBSISTENCE HARVESTS ALONG THE KUSKOKWIM RIVER. ALL PROJECTS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED BETWEEN BERING SEA FISHERMENS ASSOCIATION AND THE KUSKOKWIM RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISHCOMMISSION TO ACHIEVE GREATER COMMUNITY STABILITY.IN ADDITION, THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM SUSTAINABLE SALMON INITIATIVE WILL BOLSTER ITS PRESENCE ANDPROGRAM BY FULLY FUNDING THE STAFF NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN THE AYK SSI TO SERVE THE ARCTIC-YUKON-KUSKOKWIM TRIBAL CONSORTIUM. THE AYK SSI IS AN INDIGENOUS LED RESEARCH AND MONITORINGPROGRAM DESIGNED TO UNDERSTAND THE TRENDS AND CAUSES OF VARIATION IN SALMON ABUNDANCE ANDFISHERIES THROUGH THE ASSEMBLY OF EXISTING INFORMATION, GAINING NEW INFORMATION, AND IMPROVINGMANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION TECHNIQUES THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE AND INCLUSIVE PROCESS.

THIS ONE-TIME GRANT WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE COST OF THE 2023 ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES INVESTIGATION AND INTELLIGENCE SUMMIT (SUMMIT). THE SUMMIT WILL TAKE PLACE AT THE COEUR DALENE RESORT (115 SOUTH 2ND STREET, COEUR DALENE, IDAHO) FROM JUNE 27-29, 2023. THE RESPONSIBILITY OF PLANNING AND FUNDING EACH ANNUAL SUMMIT ROTATES AMONG THE ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES MEMBER AGENCIES  THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT HAS NOT PREVIOUSLY SPONSORED A SUMMIT. THIS SPONSORSHIP CONNECTS THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE DIRECTORS PRIORITIZATION OF COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION WITH THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE VISION OF BEING A TRUSTED PARTNER. THE 2023 SUMMITS HOSTING AGENCY IS THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME, WITH FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND LOGISTICS SUPPORT FROM FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT. THE SUMMIT PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THE OFFICE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT TO BUILD AND STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS WITH ITS STATE AND OTHER FEDERAL COUNTERPARTS. THESE RELATIONSHIPS ARE CRUCIAL TO BUILDING AN EFFECTIVE NETWORK THAT FACILITATES INFORMATION AND INTELLIGENCE SHARING AS WELL AS OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO MORE SUCCESSFULLY COMBAT WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING AND DISRUPT CRIMINAL ORGANIZATIONS OPERATING ACROSS STATE AND NATIONAL BOUNDARIES. AT THE SUMMIT, A WIDE VARIETY OF CASE STUDIES ON INVESTIGATIONS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY WILL BE SHOWCASED AND ATTENDEES WILL WORK IN GROUPS TO DISCUSS LESSONS LEARNED AND NOVEL TRENDS. DURING THESE SESSIONS, TOPICS INCLUDE INTELLIGENCE METHODS, INVESTIGATIONS TACTICS, NEW TECHNOLOGIES UTILIZED, SPECIES OF CONCERN, NEW MARKETS AND DEMANDS, CASE STUDIES, AND TRENDS. THE SUMMIT ALLOWS WILDLIFE LAW ENFORCEMENT PROFESSIONALS TO NETWORK IN A FACE-TO-FACE SETTING THAT IS MORE CONDUCIVE TO FORMING PRODUCTIVE AND LASTING COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS. THE OFFICE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT HAS PARTICIPATED IN THE SUMMIT SINCE ITS INCEPTION IN 2017. THE GOALS OF THE SUMMIT ALIGN WELL WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIORS GOAL TO BUILD AGENCY CAPACITY THROUGH STRENGTHENING COOPERATIVE RELATIONSHIPS. PARTICIPATION AND PROMOTION OF THE SUMMIT THROUGH A SPONSORSHIP UNITES FEDERAL AND STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES, WHICH DIRECTLY SERVES THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE MISSION BY INCREASING OFFICE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT-S CAPACITY THROUGH COOPERATIVE LAW ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS. WITHOUT THIS FINANCIAL SUPPORT, IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME WOULD BE UNABLE TO HOST A SUCCESSFUL SUMMIT.

PROJECT WILL RESTORE FISH PASSAGE VIA CONSTRUCTION OF A POOL AND WEIR FISHWAY AT THE CROOKED BROOK DAM IN DANFORTH, MAINE (45.659 -67.869).  FISHWAY WILL RESTORE NATIVE FISH PASSAGE TO 137 MILES OF STREAM FOR ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON AND EASTERN BROOK.  UPSTREAM ACCESS WILL BE RESTORED TO NEARLY 9,000 ACRES OF LAKE HABITAT FOR RIVER HERRING (ALOSID SPP.), WHICH ARE A KEYSTONE ECOLOGICAL SPECIES IN THE GULF OF MAINE AND A HIGHLY SOUGHT-AFTER SOURCE OF BAIT FOR COMMERCIAL LOBSTERMEN. PROJECT HAS BECOME A CENTERPIECE OF THE TOWN OF DANFORTH-S VISION FOR COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND DOWNTOWN REVITALIZATION. BEYOND CONSTRUCTION AT THE FISHWAY, CONCURRENT PLANS ARE BEING DEVELOPED TO CONSTRUCT A PUBLIC PARK ALONGSIDE THE FISHWAY, WITH RIVER ACCESS AND WALKING PATHS CONNECTING THE PARK TO THE DOWNTOWN CORE. FUTURE COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AROUND THE FISHWAY WILL INCLUDE A RIVERFRONT PARK CONNECTED TO A DOWNTOWN PEDESTRIAN CORRIDOR. TOWN OF DANFORTH EXPECTS INCREASED PUBLIC USE FOR WILDLIFE WATCHING, GATHERING, FISHING, WALKING, BIKING, AND PADDLING. PROJECT IS SHOVEL READY (ALL DESIGNS FINALIZED AND PERMITS OBTAINED).  ATLANTIC SALMON FEDERATION EXPECTS CONSTRUCTION TO COMMENCE WHEN MAINE-S IN-STREAM WORK WINDOW BEGINS ON JULY 15TH.  PROJECT SHOULD BE COMPLETED BY OCTOBER 30TH 2023. HOWEVER, TO COVER UNFORESEEN CIRCUMSTANCES, PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE IS SET TO END ON DECEMBER 31, 2024.

THE NORTH AMERICAN INTERGOVERNMENTAL COMMITTEE ON COOPERATION FOR WILDERNESS AND PROTECTED AREAS CONSERVATION (NAWPA) IS A COLLABORATIVE INITIATIVE BETWEEN LEADERS OF SIX OF THE LARGEST NORTH AMERICAN LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES. IT FOSTERS THE EXCHANGE OF IDEAS, EXPERIENCES, BEST PRACTICES, AND INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS ON SHARED CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES AT THE NORTH AMERICAN CONTINENTAL SCALE AND ACROSS MULTIPLE AGENCIES AND JURISDICTIONS.AWARD PURPOSE - THE SCOPE OF WORK IS WIDE-RANGING AND FOCUSES UPON THE PROVISION OF PROFESSIONAL SECRETARIAT SERVICES TO AN INTER-GOVERNMENTAL COMMITTEE. THE INTERNATIONAL WILDERNESS LEADERSHIP FOUNDATION (RECIPIENT) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR FACILITATION OF MEETINGS, COMMUNICATIONS, AND SUPPORT, AS DEFINED BELOW.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - SUPPORTING THE CHAIR OF STEERING COMMITTEE (SC) IN ORGANIZING AND RECORDING EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND SC MEETINGS  SUPPORTING THE TASK GROUP (TG) LEADS IN ORGANIZING AND RECORDING TASK GROUP MEETINGS BY:PRE-MEETING - DEVELOPING DISCUSSION TOPICS, GATHERING INFORMATION, COORDINATING SCHEDULES, PREPARING AND DISTRIBUTING MEETING INVITATIONS, AGENDAS, AND BRIEFING BOOKSDURING MEETING - MANAGING TECHNICAL SUPPORT, RECORDING PRIMARY DISCUSSION POINTS AND DECISIONSPOST-MEETING - DRAFTING REPORT AND DECISION SUMMARY, DISTRIBUTING MEETING DECISIONS, COORDINATING REQUESTED FOLLOW-UPS, AND FILING RECORDS.THE ANTICIPATED MEETINGS INCLUDE TWO FOR THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, SIX FOR THE STEERING COMMITTEE, AND THREE TO SIX FOR THE TASK GROUP, AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL MEETINGS, WORKSHOPS AS NEEDED AND REQUESTED BY GROUP LEADERS.DEVELOPING AS APPROPRIATE AND COORDINATING APPROVAL OF COMMITTEE MEETING DOCUMENTS, WEBSITECONTENT, AND PRODUCTS. FACILITATING COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN MEMBERS OF THE COMMITTEE GROUPS.  LIAISING WITH COMMITTEE AGENCIES FOR FOLLOW-UPS ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS, AS NEEDED.  MAINTAINING AND UPDATING CONTACT LISTS OF MEMBERS, MAINTAINING AN OPERATIONAL WEBSITE, AND A FILE SHARING SOLUTION FOR COMMITTEE DOCUMENTS.TRACKING AND REPORTING ON RECOMMENDATIONS AND DECISIONS OF THE COMMITTEE GROUPS, OUTPUTS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTION ITEMS, AND EXPENSES RELATED TO SECRETARIAT AND FACILITATION SERVICES.  PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR CONTRACTING SERVICES, AND PREPARATION OF VARIOUS COMMITTEE PRODUCTS AS NEEDED. ORGANIZING, MONITORING, AND REPORTING ON AGENCY CONTRACTS AND AGREEMENTS.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES - SUPPORT TO THE CHAIR OF THE SC WITH SCHEDULING AND ORGANIZING NAWPA EC AND SC MEETINGS, PREPARING AND DELIVERING INVITATIONS, AGENDAS, LOGISTICS, BRIEFING BOOKS AND OTHER REQUESTS.SUPPORT TO THE CHAIR OF SC AND TG LEAD WITH SCHEDULING AND ORGANIZING MEETINGS, PREPARING AND DELIVERING INVITATIONS, AGENDAS, BRIEFING BOOKS, LOGISTICS, PROGRESS REPORTS, PRODUCTS, AND REQUESTS MADE BY THE SC.REGULAR COMMUNICATION WITH AND ASSISTANCE TO THE CHAIR OF SC IN HIS HER ROLE AS LIAISON BETWEEN THE NAWPA EC CHAIR AND THE SC  TG(S).  AGENDA AND BRIEFING BOOK MATERIAL (LOGISTICS, PROGRESS REPORTS, BACKGROUND INFORMATION) FOR NAWPA EC, SC, AND TG MEETINGS APPROVED BY SC.  REPORT(S), DECISION SUMMARY(IES), PRESS RELEASE(S), AND OTHER RECORDS FROM NAWPA EC, SC, AND TG MEETINGS APPROVED BY SC.  UP-TO-DATE CONTACT LIST (ROSTER) OF THE NAWPA EC, SC, AND TG MEMBERS AND PARTNERS. OPERATIONAL AND UP-TO-DATE NAWPA COMMITTEE WEBSITE.  OPERATIONAL AND UP-TO-DATE FILE SHARING SOLUTION.  ANNUAL WORK PLAN AND BUDGET TO BE PRESENTED AT THE IN-PERSON SC MEETING.  ANNUAL FACILITATION REPORT PRESENTED TO SC, INCLUDING DETAILED REPORT ON EXPENSES.  AGENCY CONTRACT AGREEMENT REPORTS, INVOICES, AND OTHER REQUESTED FOLLOW-UPS BY SC MEMBERS.   CALENDAR OF EVENTS FOR POTENTIAL NAWPA EC, SC, AND TG PARTICIPATION (WITH SC REPRESENTATIVES).INTENDED BENEFICIARIES - THE NORTH AMERICAN INTERGOVERNMENTAL COMMITTEE ON COOPERATION FOR WILDERNESS AND PROTECTED AREAS COMMITTEE AND ITS WORKING BODIES OF STAFF MEMBERS.THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS WITH THIS GRANT AWARD.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) HAS DETERMINED THAT THE RECENT INTRODUCTION OF LARGE-SCALE LOACH(PARAMISGURNUS DABRYANUS) TO THE CALIFORNIA CENTRAL VALLEY IS A THREAT TO HABITATS THAT ARE VITAL TO THREATENEDSALMON. LARGE-SCALE LOACH IS DIFFICULT TO DETECT AND REMOVE BECAUSE IT LIVES ALONG THE BOTTOM OF THE WATER COLUMNAND IT CAN LIVE IN THE MUD WHEN CANALS OR PONDS DRY UP. QUICK AND COMPLETE REMOVAL IS THE PREFERRED APPROACH TOMANAGING INVASIVE SPECIES, BUT TRADITIONAL FISHERIES GEAR AND SURVEY METHODS MAY NOT BE SENSITIVE OR PRECISEENOUGH TO DETECT SUCH A DIFFICULT INVADER. TO INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF INVASIVE SPECIESREMOVAL EFFORTS, THE USFWS HAS PARTNERED WITH S.P. CRAMER AND  ASSOCIATES, INC., TO DEVELOP A REMOVAL PROCEDURE THATCOMBINES THE SENSITIVITY OF CUTTING-EDGE ENVIRONMENTAL DNA TECHNIQUES (ALSO KNOWN AS EDNA) WITH TRADITIONALTRAPPING METHODS. THIS HYBRID APPROACH WILL BE USED TO DETECT AND REMOVE LARGE-SCALE LOACH IN THE SAN LUISWILDLIFE REFUGE. DEVELOPING THIS METHOD WILL OCCUR IN TWO STEPS. THE FIRST STEP IS TO PERFORM AN EXPERIMENT TOCALIBRATE THE EDNA METHODOLOGY. THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE CONTEXT TO HELP INTERPRET EDNA SAMPLES. WE WILL ALSO MAKE MAPS OF THE EDNA RESULTS TO DETERMINE THE LOCATION OF ANY LARGE-SCALE LOACH EDNA HOT-SPOTS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. THE EDNA DISTRIBUTION MAPS WILL ALLOW THE USFWS TO STRATEGICALLY TARGET THEIR REMOVAL EFFORTS ACROSS A LARGER LANDSCAPE. THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO COUPLE THE SENSITIVITY OF MOLECULAR TECHNIQUES WITH PHYSICAL INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL TO DEVELOP A PROTOCOL THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO CURRENT AND FUTURE EARLY DETECTION AND ERADICATION EFFORTS. THESE NEW METHODS CAN ALSO BE APPLIED TO OTHER INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE FUTURE.

THIS AWARD HELPS TO MAKE POSSIBLE THE LARGEST ASSEMBLY OF NORTH AMERICA S CONSERVATION LEADERS FROM STATE, FEDERAL, NON GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATION (NGO) AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATION AND TOGETHER PROVIDE THE BROADEST POSSIBLE FORUM TO ADDRESS AND COORDINATE MATTERS OF SHARED CONSERVATION RESPONSIBILITY. IN COMBINATION THESE MEETINGS ALLOW FOR NATIONAL AND REGIONAL COORDINATION OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS BETWEEN STATE, FEDERAL AND NGO ENTITIES WHO WOULD BE UNABLE TO EFFECTIVELY PLAN, PROBLEM SOLVE AND COORDINATE IN ANY OTHER WAY.

KIMBLAESER, JAMES EDWARDS MILLS, BUDDY HUFFAKER, DELIA OWENS, SCOTT RUSSELL SANDERS,ROBIN WALL KIMMERER, COMBINED WITH THE LEOPOLD FOUNDATION S FOUR YOUNGCONSERVATIONISTS  LEAH BIENIAK, MARIA KENNEDY, MAX SORENSEN, AND SARAH WOODY MAKESFOR A DIVERSE GROUP OF SPEAKERS IN TERMS OF AGE, ETHNICITY, AND ROLE IN THE CONSERVATIONMOVEMENT. 2  DOUBLE LEOPOLD WEEK REGISTRATION TO 10,000 PARTICIPANTS. THE BRIDGE PROGRAM IS A PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP TO CREATE AN INCLUSIVE AND INNOVATIVE HIRING PATHWAY THAT WILL EMBOLDEN AND DIVERSIFY CONSERVATION EMPLOYMENT PRACTICES. WE HOST PEER LEARNING AND HIRING EVENTS AIMED AT CLOSING THE GAP BETWEEN QUALIFIED POTENTIAL EMPLOYEES AND EMPLOYERS IN THE CONSERVATION FIELD. OUR GOAL IS TO BUILD LEARNING AND CREATE RELATIONSHIPS FOR LONG TERM SOLUTIONS BY BRINGING TOGETHER LEADERS FROM ACROSS THE SECTOR. ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE READY TO HIRE FOR FULL TIME POSITIONS ARE INVITED TO JOIN HIRING EVENTS AND SUBMIT THEIR POSITIONS FOR CONSIDERATION. THEY WILL HAVE ACCESS TO A PRE SCREENED SET OF QUALIFIED APPLICANTS WHO HAVE THE SKILLS TO SUCCEED. THE BRIDGE TEAM WILL RECRUIT PARTICIPANTS FROM 21ST CENTURY CONSERVATION SERVICE CORPS (21CSC) AND SIMILAR PROGRAMS, SO THAT ALL CANDIDATES WILL COME TO THE EVENT HAVING ALREADY HAD INITIAL WORK EXPERIENCES IN CONSERVATION, RECREATION, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, OR EXPERIENTIAL EDUCATION. THE BRIDGE TEAM WILL IDENTIFY A DIVERSE GROUP OF CANDIDATES FOR THE EVENT, WITH A FOCUS ON ELEVATING UNDERREPRESENTED APPLICANTS, AND WILL MATCH CANDIDATES WITH EMPLOYERS BASED ON THE SKILLS NEEDED FOR EACH POSITION BEING OFFERED AT THE EVENT. ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE NOT HIRING THROUGH THE BRIDGE PROJECT CAN SPONSOR THE INITIATIVE TO HAVE ACCESS TO THE PRE EVENT TRAININGS, CROSS SECTOR LEARNING AND NETWORKING OPPORTUNITIES, AND FACILITATED HIRING THROUGHOUT THE YEAR.

BIRDSCARIBBEAN AND THE SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION TRUST WILL WORK TOGETHER TO MAINTAIN WOODBOURNE SHOREBIRD REFUGE, ON BARBADOS, PROVIDING HABITAT FOR MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS AND OTHER WATERBIRDS AWAY FROM HUNTING PRESSURE. THIS INCLUDES THE CONTINUED MANAGEMENT OF SHOREBIRD FOR AGING HABITATS AND MENTORING OF LOCAL PERSONNEL TO FACILITATE SITE MAINTENANCE AND WATERBIRD SURVEYS. THE CARETAKER OF THE REFUGE WILL ALSO MAINTAIN COMMUNICATION WITH THE ACTIVE SHOOTING SWAMPS ON THE ISLAND IN RELATION TO HARVEST LEVELS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DOCUMENT ECOLOGICAL EFFECTS ON SEA OTTER POPULATIONS AND KEY MARINERESOURCES IN THE SITKA SOUND AREA RESULTING FROM INCREASED SEA OTTER HUNTING AND THE TRADITIONAL PRODUCTIONOF SEA OTTER HANDICRAFTS THAT OCCURRED THROUGH MODERN INDIGENOUS SEA OTTER MANAGEMENT PRACTICESSPANNING APPROXIMATELY 20 YEARS. WHILE SEA OTTER RECOLONIZATION IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA HAS RESULTED INCONFLICTS WITH MODERN SHELLFISHERIES (SUBSISTENCE, COMMERCIAL, AND SPORT), THE SITKA SOUND EXAMPLEPROVIDES A CASE STUDY WHEREBY THE EXTENT OF SEA OTTER INFLUENCE ON THE NEARSHORE ECOSYSTEM WAS REDUCEDWITHOUT THEIR LOCAL EXTIRPATION, AND SUBSISTENCE SHELLFISHERIES HAVE BEEN RESTORED (AT LEAST PARTIALLY). OTHERLOCAL ECOSYSTEM RESPONSES HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED.THIS CASE STUDY WILL PROVIDE THE HISTORICAL CONTEXT AND CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS THAT LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OFTHE MODERN MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN PLACE TODAY. THESE PRACTICES WERE DEVELOPED UNDER PROVISIONS OF THEMARINE MAMMAL PROTECT ACT AND WERE DESIGNED TO HELP REDUCE SEA OTTER PREDATION OF MARINE RESOURCES INAREAS IMPORTANT TO SUBSISTENCE WITHOUT IMPACTING OVERALL SEA OTTER ABUNDANCE. CONCURRENTLY, THEREVITALIZATION OF TRADITIONAL HANDICRAFT PRODUCTION WAS ENCOURAGED THROUGH PUBLIC POLICY ADVOCACY ANDPROVISION OF COMMUNITY CLASSES IN SEA OTTER SKIN SEWING USING THE PRODUCTS OF THE HUNT, PRIMARILY TANNEDHIDES, THEREBY CONTRIBUTING TO CULTURAL REVITALIZATION AND LOCAL VILLAGE ECONOMIES WHERE JOBS ARE SCARCE.THE COOPERATION AND COLLABORATION AMONG ALASKA NATIVE HUNTERS AND HANDICRAFTERS, A LOCAL TRIBE, ANDSEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTE WERE HALLMARKS OF THE PROCESS.THE LOCAL SEA OTTER HARVEST MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IN SITKA SOUND WERE CARRIED OUT EXCLUSIVELY BY ALASKANATIVES AND OFFER A PATHWAY TO IMPLEMENTING TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT CANBALANCE SUSTAINABLE SEA OTTER CONSERVATION EFFORTS WITH HUMAN NEEDS FROM ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. VIEWINGSEA OTTER POPULATIONS AND THE HUMAN COMMUNITIES THAT HARVEST THEM AS A COUPLED SOCIO-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMMAY IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT OVERALL AND ENABLE A MOSAIC OF COEXISTENCE.PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: REVIEW AND SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING LITERATURE DOCUMENTING THE LOCAL ECOLOGICAL EFFECTS OF THEINCREASED SEA OTTER HARVEST PRESSURE AROUND SITKA SOUND THAT RESULTED AS SEA OTTERS WERE DISPLACEDOR DIMINISHED AT VERY LOCAL SCALES NEAR TO WHERE INDIGENOUS HARVEST INTENSITY WAS GREATEST  INFORMATIONAL INTERVIEWS WITH ALASKA NATIVE HUNTERS AND CRAFTSPEOPLE, SEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTESTAFF, AND TRIBES INVOLVED IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INDIGENOUS MANAGEMENTINITIATIVES AND STRATEGIES OVER THE 20-YEAR PERIOD  AND DOCUMENTATION OF ALASKA NATIVE-LED INITIATIVES AND PROGRAMS PERTAINING TO THE LOCALIZEDDEVELOPMENT OF INDIGENOUS SEA OTTER MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES IN THE SITKA SOUND AREA AND THEIRIMPLICATIONS FOR COLLABORATIVE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING PUBLIC POLICY ADVOCACY THATRESULTED IN A CONCISE DEFINITION OF SIGNIFICANTLY ALTERED FOR THE USE OF SEA OTTERS IN ALASKA NATIVETRADITIONAL ART, CLOTHING, AND HANDICRAFTS.INTERVIEWS WILL BE RECORDED AND TRANSCRIBED AND A THEMATIC ANALYSIS WILL BE PERFORMED TO ASSIST IN THEDEVELOPMENT OF A FINAL REPORT.THE PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A FINAL REPORT THAT WILL BE SUITABLE FOR PUBLICATION. PROJECTDELIVERABLES WILL PROVIDE FOUNDATIONS FOR DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE CO-MANAGEMENT STRATEGIESFOR SEA OTTERS, OFFERING INSIGHTS FOR WHAT MAKES A SUCCESSFUL COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ALASKANATIVE PEOPLE, LOCAL TRIBES, AND THE U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE AND STRENGTHENING A COLLABORATIVERELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTE AND THE SERVICE. THIS PROJECT RESPONDS TO NEEDSDETERMINED BY THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA SEA OTTER STAKEHOLDER WORKING GROUP AND A CONGRESSIONAL REQUESTTO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ECOLOGICAL IMPLICATIONS OF SEA OTTER RECOVERY ACROSS SOUTHEAST ALASKA AND TOASSESS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.

AWARD PURPOSE:  THE SECRETARIAT OPERATIONS ARE ESSENTIAL TO DELIVER ON ALL ASPECTS OF THECAFF WORKING GROUP S MANDATE TO ADDRESS THE CONSERVATION OF ARCTIC BIODIVERSITY, AND TO COMMUNICATEFINDINGS TO THE GOVERNMENTS AND RESIDENTS OF THE ARCTIC, HELPING TO PROMOTE PRACTICES, WHICH ENSURE THESUSTAINABLE USE OF THE ARCTICS LIVING RESOURCES. CAFF SERVES AS A VEHICLE TO COOPERATE ON SPECIES ANDHABITAT MANAGEMENT AND UTILIZATION, TO SHARE INFORMATION ON MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES AND REGULATORYREGIMES, AND TO FACILITATE MORE KNOWLEDGEABLE DECISION-MAKING. IT PROVIDES A MECHANISM TO DEVELOPCOMMON RESPONSES ON ISSUES OF IMPORTANCE FOR THE ARCTIC ECOSYSTEM SUCH AS DEVELOPMENT ANDECONOMIC PRESSURES, CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES AND POLITICAL COMMITMENTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ORGANIZATIONAL MANAGEMENT OF CAFF, PROGRAM MANAGEMENT, ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT,AND DATA MANAGEMENT. EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES:CAFF STAFFING CAPACITY REMAINS IN PLACE OR INCREASES BY 2025, AND IS SUFFICIENT TO ENSURE EFFECTIVEOPERATION AND EXECUTION OF SECRETARIAT FUNCTIONS. CAFF OPERATING COSTS (RENT, OFFICE SUPPLIES, ETC.) ARE FULLY SUPPORTED BY CONTRIBUTIONS FROM MEMBER COUNTRIES EACH YEAR. CAFF SECRETARIAT STAFF HAVE THE NECESSARY SUPPORT TO TRAVEL TO RELEVANT MEETINGS TO SUPPORT THE DELIVERY OF THE CAFF MANDATE, IMPLEMENT CAFF MANAGEMENT BOARD PRIORITY EFFORTS, AND OR KEY PROJECTS PROGRAMS INITIATIVES EACH YEAR.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: ALL MEMBER NATIONS OF THE CAFF

ANCHORAGE SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT IS COORDINATING THE DEVELOPMENT OF 5 SMALL-SCALE LOCAL NATIVE PLANT NURSERIES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH WASILLA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, PALMER SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, KNIK TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND EKLUTNA TRIBAL CONSERVATION DISTRICT. ADDITIONAL PARTNERS AND VOLUNTEERS INCLUDE GOVERNMENT HILL COMMUNITY MEMBERS, NATIVE PLANT SOCIETY MEMBERS, AND DISTRICT BOARD MEMBERS. EACH OF THE 5 LOCATIONS WILL HAVE ITS OWN UNIQUE SET UP AND MAY INVESTIGATE DIFFERENT PROPAGATION METHODS, GERMINATION TECHNIQUES, OR NATIVE PLANT SPECIES TO GROW. FOR YEAR 1, THE PARTNERSHIP HAS SELECTED 6 ALASKA NATIVE PLANT SPECIES OF CONSERVATION VALUE TO BEGIN GROWING FOR THE EVENTUAL END USE IN ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION PROJECTS THROUGHOUT SOUTHCENTRAL ALASKA. A PART TIME PROJECT MANAGER HAS BEEN HIRED BY ANCHORAGE SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT TO COORDINATE BETWEEN THE DIFFERENT LOCATIONS AND PARTNERS. THE PLANT MATERIALS CENTER HAS AGREED TO GERMINATE THE PLANTS FOR US AS WE BUILD OUT THE NURSERIES. ADF G, USFWS, CHUGACH NF, AND OTHER AGENCY PARTNERS ALL SUPPORT THE PROGRAM AND ARE LOOKING FORWARD TO HAVING NATIVE PLANTS TO USE IN CONSERVATION PROJECTS. HAVING THESE PLANTS TO DIVERSIFY PLANTINGS WILL BE OF TREMENDOUS BENEFIT FOR THE CONSERVATION OF TRUST SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS.

THESE GRANTS WILL SUPPORT A LIMITEDNUMBER OF NYCALC PARTICIPANTS PROJECTS THAT MEET OUR CRITERIA.

PROTECTING BATS AND THEIR HABITATS IS STRATEGIC ACTION TO REDUCE ZOONOTIC PATHOGEN SPILLOVER RISK. THE MENTOR-BATS: CHAMPIONS OF BATS AND THEIR HABITATS FOR GLOBAL HEALTH USES THE SUCCESSFUL USFWS MENTOR FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM MODEL TO INCREASE GLOBAL CAPACITY FOR CONSERVATION BY INVESTING IN EARLY-CAREER PROFESSIONALS. MENTOR-BATS WILL BUILD A TEAM OF TRANSDISCIPLINARY FELLOWS IN PRIORITY REGIONS AND PROVIDE RESOURCES, TRAINING, AND ENDURING RELATIONSHIPS TO CREATE AND SUSTAIN CONSERVATION INITIATIVES THAT BENEFIT BATS, PEOPLE, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. THE PROGRAM INCORPORATES EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN THE FIELD, DIRECT MENTORSHIP, VIRTUAL LEARNING, PARTICIPATION IN EXISTING BAT CONSERVATION NETWORKS AND WORKING GROUPS, AND COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS TO EMPOWER AND GROW CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY RESOLVABLE THREATS AND PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS FOR PROTECTING VULNERABLE BAT POPULATIONS AND ADVANCING ONE HEALTH PRIORITIES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF MENTOR-BATS IS INCREASED PROFESSIONAL CAPACITY AND CONSERVATION LEADERSHIP TO ENACT GOOD CONSERVATION PRACTICE IN AREAS WITH HIGH BAT-HUMAN INTERFACE. MENTOR-BATS WILL MEET THE URGENT NEED TO ENACT CONSERVATION PLANS TO PROTECT BATS AND PEOPLE IN PRIORITY AREAS AND DEVELOP CONSERVATION LEADERS TO MEET THE CHALLENGES OF THE FUTURE.

THIS PROJECT EXPANDS ON EFFORTS TO DEVELOP NOVEL TECHNIQUES TO QUANTIFY WILDLIFE ABUNDANCE, INCLUDING CONDUCTING AERIAL WATERFOWL SURVEYS WITH UNOCCUPIED AERIAL SYSTEMS (UAS) AND TERRESTRIAL LARGE MAMMAL SURVEYS USING CAMERA TRAPS. THIS STAGE OF THE EFFORT WILL FOCUS ON WINTERING HABITAT AREAS IN NEW MEXICO AND TEXAS BY DEPLOYING AN UAS TO IMAGE WATERFOWL AND CRANES ON REFUGES, IDENTIFY THEM BY TYPE, AND PROVIDE DATA DESCRIBING WATERFOWL TYPE AND LOCATION TO THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) TO SUBSEQUENTLY ANALYZE FOR ABUNDANCE ESTIMATION. THIS WORK IS OPERATIONAL, RUNNING THE WORKFLOW FROM IMAGE COLLECTION, IMAGERY CORRECTION, ANIMAL IDENTIFICATION, AND DATA OUTPUT. SIMULTANEOUSLY, THIS WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP METHODS FOR AUTOMATED ABUNDANCE ESTIMATION FROM CAMERA TRAPS AND LABELING SPECIES WITHIN ARCHIVAL CAMERA TRAP IMAGERY. BOTH EFFORTS RELY HEAVILY ON CITIZEN SCIENCE. OVERALL, THIS WORK WILL SUBSTANTIALLY ELEVATE THE USE OF REMOTE IMAGERY ACQUISITION TO ACQUIRE PRIORITY BIOLOGICAL DATA. SUCH WORK IS LESS EXPENSIVE TO ACQUIRE REMOTELY AND SAFER FOR EMPLOYEES. THE FWS WILL ACQUIRE MORE SPECIES DATA THAN PREVIOUSLY POSSIBLE, SUBSTANTIALLY ENRICHING ANALYSES, THEREBY PRODUCING MORE INFORMED, TARGETED AND EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.

FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE SCHOLARSHIPS AND TO FACILITATE THE PARTICIPATION OF FOUR YOUNG PEOPLE AS SPEAKERS IN A SCHEDULED PANEL.

THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIONS LAID OUT IN THIS PROPOSAL DEMONSTRATE HOW THE COLOMBIAN PACIFICREGIONAL PROTECTED AREAS SYSTEM (SIRAP), WILL EXPAND STRATEGIC ALLIANCES WITHIN ITS MEMBERS TOINCREASE PROTECTION FOR SHOREBIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS AND THEREFORE ADVANCE THE OBJECTIVES ANDGOALS OF THE PACIFIC AMERICAS SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY. CONSERVATION AND MONITORING ATKEY SITES WILL BE CULTIVATED AND INCREASED. PARTNERS WILL BE ASSISTED IN REBUILDING THEIR CAPACITYAND UNDERSTANDING OF THE ECOLOGICAL RELATIONSHIPS WITHIN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS, AND LOCALCOMMUNITIES WILL REAP THE BENEFITS OF PROTECTING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THIS PROPOSAL WILLCONTRIBUTE TO A REGIONAL SCOPE PERSPECTIVE, INCREASE THE AWARENESS OF THE VALUE OF SHOREBIRDCONSERVATION THROUGH MONITORING, IMPROVE THE LOCAL CAPACITY AND KNOWLEDGE TO PARTICIPATE INLOCAL DECISION-MAKING. THIS TYPE OF PARTNERSHIP AND COORDINATED REGIONAL EFFORTS AREINDISPENSABLE IN A POST-PANDEMIC SCENARIO, BECAUSE MANY LOCAL COMMUNITIES ARE NOW HIGHLY VULNERABLE DUE TO THEIR GEOGRAPHIC ISOLATION AND LACK OF GOVERNMENT ASSISTANCE. TO CONTINUEPROGRESSING OUR KNOWLEDGE AND EVALUATION OF SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS' CONSERVATION STATUS, WEWILL IMPLEMENT A PARTICIPATORY MONITORING SYSTEM THAT ENGAGES THE COMMUNITIES AND LOCALAUTHORITIES. THE DATA GAINED FROM THIS MONITORING WILL FORM THE BENCHMARK FOR EVALUATING THEEFFECTIVENESS OF MANAGEMENT AND DEVELOPMENT PLANS. THE DATA WILL ENABLE THE PARTNERSHIP TOMAKE INFORMED DECISIONS IN THE PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT OF THEIR TERRITORIES, WHICH ARE BEINGIMPLEMENTED IN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE SIRAP. DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS PROJECT,GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, COMMUNITY GROUPS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS WILL WORK TOGETHER FOR THECONSERVATION OF SHOREBIRD HABITATS, WHICH PROVIDE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES TO HUMANS AND OTHERWILDLIFE. THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT LOCAL COMMUNITIES, WHILE ALSO ACHIEVING THE CONSERVATION OFSHOREBIRDS, MANY THAT BREED IN THE USA, ACROSS THE ENTIRE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY.

WETLANDS ON THE PACIFIC COAST OF THE AMERICAS PROVIDE CRITICAL HABITATS FOR MILLIONS OF MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS. SHOREBIRDS ARE THREATENED BY COASTAL DEVELOPMENT, RECREATIONAL DISTURBANCES, AND CLIMATE CHANGE. WE WILL BUILD ON PREVIOUS COORDINATION EFFORTS TO DELIVER CONSERVATION SOLUTIONS TO A NETWORK OF 100 PARTNERS THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY. WE WILL LEVERAGE AUDUBON'S EXPERTISE AND RESOURCES TO DIVERSIFY THE PARTNERSHIP TO INCLUDE PRACTITIONERS FROM DIVERSE CONSERVATION SECTORS (E.G., CLIMATE CHANGE, BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION, POVERTY ALLEVIATION). THE PACIFIC SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION INITIATIVE WILL 1) REDUCE THE THREAT OF HUMAN DISTURBANCE AT 5 KEY SHOREBIRD SITES WITHIN THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY IN LATIN AMERICA; 2) DEVELOP GUIDANCE FOR PARTNERS TO SECURE SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION VIA MAINSTREAMING SHOREBIRD PROTECTIONS INTO BIODIVERSITY, CLIMATE CHANGE AND INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS; AND 3) SECURE THE MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION OF CRITICAL SHOREBIRD HABITATS BY INTEGRATING SHOREBIRD SPECIFIC-CRITERIA INTO SUBNATIONAL LANDS PROTECTION PLANNING PROGRAMS (CONSERVA AVES).

THE MAGNITUDE, IMPACT, AND SPATIAL VARIATION OF MANY THREATS TO SHOREBIRDS ALONG THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. UNDERSTANDING WHICH FACTORS ARE HAVING THE GREATEST IMPACT AT DIFFERENT SITES WILL HELP FOCUS CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO BE MOST EFFECTIVE. SOME THREATS SUCH AS HABITAT LOSS AND HUMAN DISTURBANCE ARE MORE IMMEDIATE WHEREAS THE IMPACTS OF SEA-LEVEL RISE MAY BE FURTHER OFF IN TIME BUT REQUIRE PLANNING NOW. HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND SEA-LEVEL RISE ARE BOTH IDENTIFIED AS THREATS OF HIGH OR VERY HIGH CONCERN IN THE PACIFIC AMERICAS SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY AND REQUIRE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES TO REDUCE AND/OR ADAPT TO THESE THREATS. IN RECENT WORK, THE 13-COUNTRY MIGRATORY SHOREBIRD PROJECT (MSP) HAS COLLECTED DATA TO DOCUMENT THE MAGNITUDE AND RELATIVE DEGREE OF EXPOSURE OF IMPORTANT SITES FROM MEXICO TO CHILE TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND SEA-LEVEL RISE. THERE IS OPPORTUNITY TO LEVERAGE THAT WORK TO UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF THESE THREATS MORE FULLY AND MORE SO TO IDENTIFY WHAT CONSERVATION STRATEGIES CAN BE IMPLEMENTED TO MITIGATE THE THREATS. WE WILL STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF NATIONAL STAKEHOLDERS TO ADDRESS THESE TWO THREATS. TO DO THIS WE WILL USE EXISTING DATA AND THE MSP PARTNER NETWORK TO 1) QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF DISTURBANCE ACROSS 84 SITES FROM MEXICO TO CHILE AND WORK WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AT SITES WITH HIGH RATES OF DISTURBANCE TO IDENTIFY AND IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES TO REDUCE DISTURBANCE AND 2) ASSESS THE CAPACITY OF WESTERN HEMISPHERE SHOREBIRD RESERVE NETWORK (WHSRN) SITES ON THE PACIFIC COAST OF THE AMERICAS TO ADAPT TO SEA-LEVEL RISE AND WORK WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO IDENTIFY THE PATHWAYS (E.G., POLICY, ZONING) TOWARDS IMPLEMENTING ADAPTATION STRATEGIES. THE PROJECT WILL REACH OUT TO THE RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH WEBINAR/WORKSHOPS ABOUT OUR FINDINGS TO DETERMINE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS AND WHETHER CHANGES IN MANAGEMENT CAN BE MADE. WHERE POSSIBLE, WE WILL WORK WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO IMPLEMENT DISTURBANCE MITIGATION MEASURES. WE WILL QUANTIFY THE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY OF WHSRN SITES SHOWN TO HAVE HIGH POTENTIAL EXPOSURE TO SEA-LEVEL RISE. WE WILL CONSIDER METRICS SUCH AS THE DISTANCE TO EXISTING ROADS, LEVEES, CURRENT LAND COVER, AND OWNERSHIP, PROTECTION STATUS, AND THE DISTANCE TO HUMAN COMMUNITIES AMONG OTHER METRICS TO CHARACTERIZE THE RELATIVE ADAPTIVE CAPACITY AT DIFFERENT SITES. WE WILL THEN WORK WITH LOCAL PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY STRATEGIES TO COMMUNICATE FINDINGS TO RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS (E.G., POLICY-MAKERS; LAND ZONING, ETC.) THAT MAY HELP TO FULLY DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ADAPTATION STRATEGIES.THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT FOUR CONSERVATION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED BY THE PACIFIC AMERICAS SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY AND AT LEAST NINE FOCAL SPECIES OF THE STRATEGY. IMPLEMENTED ACTIONS WILL BENEFIT LOCAL PARTNERS AND COMMUNITIES AND THOSE COMMITTED TO THE CONSERVATION OF SHOREBIRDS ACROSS THE FLYWAY. SHOREBIRDS, INCLUDING THOSE BREEDING IN THE USA, AND THEIR HABITATS WILL BENEFIT ALONG THE ENTIRE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY. POINT BLUE WILL BE SUB-CONTRACTING WITH ASOCIACION PARA EL ESTUDIO Y CONSERVACION DE LAS AVES ACUATICAS EN COLOMBIA AND THE CENTRO DE INVESTIGACIN CIENTFICA Y DE EDUCACIN SUPERIOR DE ENSENADA, BAJA CALIFORNIA.

DESPITE THE WELL-DOCUMENTED IMPORTANCE OF NORTHWEST MEXICO FOR THE MIGRATION AND SURVIVAL OF SHOREBIRDS ALONG THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY, THIS GROUP OF BIRDS AND THE CONSERVATION OF ITS HABITAT IN THIS REGION REMAIN NEGLECTED IN PUBLIC POLICY, MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND ALL OTHER FEDERAL, STATE, OR MUNICIPAL REGULATIONS OR POLICIES. FOR THAT REASON, SHOREBIRDS AND THEIR HABITAT ARE EXPOSED TO THE CUMULATIVE IMPACTS CAUSED BY, FOR EXAMPLE, TOURISM DEVELOPMENT, RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, WATER CONTROL AND IRRIGATION WORKS COMBINED WITH THE CONTINUOUS PRESSURE AND POLLUTION CAUSED BY AGRICULTURE, FISHING, AND AQUACULTURE. ALL OF THESE THREATS HAVE CAUSED THE LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF SOME OF THE REGIONS WETLANDS, A PROBLEM THAT IS MOST PRONOUNCED IN THE COASTAL LAGOONS ALONG THE CONTINENTAL COASTLINE BECAUSE OF EXPANSIVE AND INTENSE AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT IN THAT REGION.THE OUTCOME OF OUR ACTIONS IN THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT PRIORITY SHOREBIRD HABITAT.TO DO SO, WE REGULARLY MONITOR SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS IN NORTHWEST MEXICO AS A TOOL TO EVALUATE AND ADAPT WETLAND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, AND COLLABORATE IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SITE-SPECIFIC CONSERVATION OR RESTORATION INITIATIVES. TO FACILITATE COLLABORATION AND STEWARDSHIP, WE MAINTAIN DATA ON THE STATUS OF SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS AND HABITATS WHICH IS AVAILABLE AND ACCESSIBLE FOR LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL USE. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT RELATIVE TO DATA COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION INCLUDE 1) CONDUCTING A BIANNUAL SHOREBIRD SURVEY OF 10 PRIORITY WETLANDS; 2) CONTINUING INSTALLATION OF THE FIRST COLLABORATIVE NETWORK OF MOTUS STATIONS IN PRIORITY WETLANDS; AND 3) WORKING WITH FEDERAL AGENCIES TO REVIEW, IMPROVE, AND REVISE THE RECENTLY DRAFTED NATIONAL ACTION PLAN FOR SHOREBIRDS AND PROMOTE ITS PUBLICATION AND ADOPTION.WITH THE PURPOSE OF INCREASING LOCAL STEWARDSHIP FOR SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION IN COMMUNITIES ADJACENT TO PRIORITY WETLANDS, WE WILL 1) OFFER LOCAL SCHOOL TEACHERS, COMMUNITY PROMOTERS, PARK RANGERS, AND VOLUNTEERS FORMAL AND INFORMAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR EDUCATION AND TRAINING ON SHOREBIRD AND WETLAND CONSERVATION TOPICS; 2) WORK WITH THE LOCAL UNIVERSITY TO OFFER A DIPLOMA TO CONSERVATION PRACTITIONERS AND PARK RANGERS ON TOOLS TO DRIVE BEHAVIORAL CHANGE FOR THE CONSERVATION OF SHOREBIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS; AND 3) REVISE OUR USER-FRIENDLY, SITE-BASED DASHBOARDS THAT PROVIDE EASY-TO-UNDERSTAND INFORMATION ON SHOREBIRD ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION TRENDS, AND CURRENT OR POTENTIAL THREATS FOR USE BY LOCAL COMMUNITIES, AGENCIES, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. IMPLEMENTED ACTIONS WILL BENEFIT ALL PARTNERS AND COMMUNITIES COMMITTED TO THE CONSERVATION OF SHOREBIRDS, INCLUDING THOSE BREEDING IN THE USA, AND THEIR HABITATS ALONG THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY.

IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE AIM TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM VIABILITY OF THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER POPULATION OF NORTHWESTERN MEXICO BY IDENTIFYING AND MANAGING THE MOST PRESSING THREATS TO ITS SURVIVAL IN THE MOST CRITICALLY IMPORTANT AREAS OF ITS DISTRIBUTION. THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER IS A FOCAL SPECIES OF THE PACIFIC AMERICAS SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY AND IS LISTED AS ENDANGERED BY THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT. THE COASTS OF SINALOA, AND THE ASSOCIATED BARRIER ISLANDS IN PARTICULAR, REPRESENT THE MOST IMPORTANT HABITATS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THIS SUBSPECIES. CRITICAL THREATS TO THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER WILL BE IDENTIFIED BY MONITORING SURVIVAL, HABITAT USE, AND BREEDING SUCCESS, AND SPECIFIC SITES WILL BE FLAGGED AS PRIORITY AREAS FOR FUTURE CONSERVATION ACTIONS. THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER IS AN UMBRELLA SPECIES IN THE REGION, AND THIS PROJECT WILL POSITIVELY AFFECT MANY SPECIES THAT SHARE HABITAT WITH THIS IMPORTANT SUBSPECIES. FOCUSING CONSERVATION EFFORTS ON THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER WILL PROVIDE SOLUTIONS FOR MULTIPLE PROBLEMS THAT ARE SHARED AMONG THE OTHER 12 SPECIES OF BIRDS THAT BREED IN THE COASTAL DUNE HABITATS OF THE REGION. HUMAN ACTIVITIES HAVE GENERATED CHANGES IN COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS THAT HAVE ALLOWED NEW THREATS, SUCH AS PREDATOR INTRUSIONS AND VARIOUS FORMS OF DISTURBANCE, TO APPEAR IN HIGHLY VULNERABLE SITES INHABITED BY AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHERS. THESE THREATS AFFECT BREEDING SUCCESS AND PUT INDIVIDUAL SURVIVAL AND POPULATION VIABILITY AT RISK IN THE LONG TERM. FORTUNATELY, THESE THREATS AND THEIR CONSEQUENCES CAN BE PREVENTED, MINIMIZED, OR EVEN REVERSED THROUGH SURVEILLANCE AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS. TO THIS END, WE PROPOSE ACTIONS THAT INCLUDE MONITORING AND BANDING AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHERS IN THREE IMPORTANT COASTAL LAGOONS OF SINALOA TO ACCURATELY ESTIMATE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, USE OF WINTER HABITAT, AND LOCAL SURVIVAL. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP TO DETERMINE THE POPULATION STATUS OF AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHERS DURING THEIR ANNUAL CYCLE, WHILE PROVIDING A FOUNDATION FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. FURTHERMORE, COMMUNITY RANGERS WILL BE TRAINED TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION MATERIALS IN THE FORM OF SIGNAGE WILL BE DEVELOPED TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN PRIORITY SITES. DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THIS PROJECT, FEDERAL AGENCIES, COMMUNITY GROUPS, AND ACADEMICS WILL WORK TOGETHER IN CLOSE COLLABORATION TO IMPROVE THE STATUS OF OYSTERCATCHERS AND OTHER BREEDING MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES SHARED WITH THE USA. IMPLEMENTED ACTIONS WILL BENEFIT ALL PARTNERS AND COMMUNITIES COMMITTED TO THE CONSERVATION OF SHOREBIRDS AND THEIR HABITATS ALONG THE PACIFIC AMERICAS FLYWAY.

PROJECT ABSTRACT:BIG OCEAN SEEKS SUPPORT TO GROW AND STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN AND AMONGST LSMPA SITES AND MANAGERS, LEVERAGE LESSONS LEARNED TO INCREASE BEST-PRACTICE MANAGEMENT RESOURCES, AND TO AMPLIFY THE IMPORTANCE OF THE GENRE AS A TOOL FOR NATIONAL, REGIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL OCEAN PROTECTION AND GOVERNANCE AS WE NAVIGATE TOWARDS THE GLOBAL CONSERVATION TARGETS OF 20 X 2030.STATEMENT OF NEED:ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF LARGE-SCALE MARINE PROTECTED (AND MANAGED) AREAS (LSMPA) SITES AND MANAGERS IS CRITICAL, NOW MORE THAN EVER. AS VAST MARINE MANAGED AREAS CAN ACT AS SENTINEL SITES THE INCREASED IMPACTS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE, MANAGEMENT TEAMS CAN FACILITATE THE RELATIONSHIPS AND RESEARCH NECESSARY TO PROVIDE A BASELINE FOR WHAT BIOPHYSICAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE STRATEGIES MUST SEEK TO MATCH AND EXCEED WORLDWIDE. BEST-PRACTICE MANAGEMENT IS THE REQUISITE FRAMEWORK TO ENSURE THESE VAST MARINE PROTECTED AREAS, AND THE COUNTRIES AND COMMUNITIES INEXTRICABLY TIED TO THEM, ARE VIABLE FOR THE LONG TERM.ONE MIGHT SUGGEST THAT MPAS BROADLY ARE IMPORTANT BUT VAST MPAS PROVIDE UNIQUE BENEFITS AND ARE ULTIMATELY THE FOUNDATION OF GLOBAL OCEAN PROTECTION. AT PRESENT THERE ARE CLOSE TO 17,000 MPAS OF ALL SIZES, SCALES, AND LEVELS OF IMPLEMENTATION AND PROTECTION. HOWEVER, 73% OF CURRENT GLOBAL MARINE PROTECTION COMES FROM THE 41 ESTABLISHED AND IMPLEMENTED LSMPAS THAT ARE E 100,000 KM2. THAT MEANS ALL 18 MEMBER SITES OF BIG OCEAN, PLUS SEVERAL SITES BEING SUPPORTED BY THE BLUE NATURE ALLIANCE AND ITS PARTNERS. ADDITIONALLY, OF THESE SITES, ONLY THREE HAVE MANAGEMENT PLANS THAT HAVE BEEN IN PLACE FOR MORE THAN 10 YEARS; CONSIDERING MOST SITES WERE ESTABLISHED IN THE LAST FIVE YEARS, THE NEED FOR BEST-PRACTICE RESOURCES FOR MANAGERS AND STAKEHOLDERS AND RIGHTS-HOLDERS IS VITAL IF THE WORLD HOPES TO EXPERIENCE THE BENEFITS TO HUMANITY THAT LSMPAS CAN HELP TO PROVIDE.

THE CANAL OF JAMBELI IS A CRITICAL WINTERING AREA FOR 19 SHOREBIRD SPECIES, INCLUDING FIVE FOCAL SPECIES OF THE PACIFIC AMERICAS SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION STRATEGY, AND IS A WHSRN SITE OF INTERNATIONAL IMPORTANCE. IN 1999, ECUADOR DEVELOPED A LEGAL FRAMEWORK TO SECURE THE CONSERVATION OF MANGROVE FOREST AND GRANTED CONCESSIONS TO DO SUSTAINABLY FISHERIES TO ANCESTRAL COMMUNITIES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) STRENGTHEN THE ADMINISTRATIVE CAPACITIES OF BENEFICIARIES TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF A SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITY TOURISM MODEL; 2) PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO MUNICIPALITIES TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED COASTAL MANAGEMENT PLANS TO CONSERVE 111,197 ACRES OF MANGROVES; AND 3) DETERMINE CHANGES IN MANGROVE FOREST COVER OVER THE LAST 15 YEARS IN CONCESSION AREAS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1) DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING CAPACITY-BUILDING WORKSHOPS, 2) TESTING A SUSTAINABLE ECOTOURISM MODEL, 3) HOLDING WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP INTEGRATED COASTAL MANAGEMENT PLANS, AND 4) MAPPING CHANGES IN MANGROVE COVER AND MICRO-TOPOGRAPHIC VARIABLES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES ARE 500 FAMILIES FROM CONCESSIONARIES AND TWO MUNICIPALITIES. CONSERVATION OF MANGROVES PROVIDES ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT WILL BENEFIT THE WELL-BEING OF LOCAL HUMAN COMMUNITIES AND U.S. CITIZENS THROUGH CARBON STORAGE.

ENVIRONMENTAL DNA  EDNA  IS DNA SHED BY LIVING ORGANISMS INTO THE ENVIRONMENT THROUGHSLOUGHED SKIN OR SCALES, MUCUS, FECES, OR URINE  QUANTITATIVE PCR  QPCR , HIGH THROUGHPUTSEQUENCING, OR CRISPR BASED TECHNIQUES CAN DETECT EDNA IN ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, ALLOWINGBIOLOGISTS TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF A SPECIES AT A SAMPLING LOCATION WITHOUTHAVING TO DIRECTLY OBSERVE OR CAPTURE ORGANISMS  EDNA DETECTION EXPLOITS DNA BARCODES, ORGENE REGIONS THAT VARY BETWEEN TAXA, AND CAN TARGET SINGLE SPECIES OR MULTIPLE SPECIES  SINGLESPECIES DETECTION, WHICH IS USEFUL WHEN ONLY ONE OR A SMALL NUMBER OF SPECIES ARE TARGETED,INVOLVES AMPLIFICATION OF A SPECIES SPECIFIC SEQUENCE ON A QPCR MACHINE OR A HANDHELDFLUORESCENCE READER  MULTI SPECIES DETECTION, ALSO KNOWN AS EDNA METABARCODING, USESUNIVERSAL PRIMERS TO AMPLIFY ONE OR MORE BARCODING REGIONS FOR ALL DNA IN A SAMPLE  THESEAMPLIFIED REGIONS THEN UNDERGO HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING AND ARE SORTED BIOINFORMATICALLY EDNA METABARCODING CAN PROVIDE COMMUNITY LEVEL INVENTORIES OF SAMPLING LOCATIONS WHICH CANBE USEFUL FOR MANAGING ECOSYSTEMS WHERE BIODIVERSITY IS POORLY CHARACTERIZED  UNDER THISCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT AN INITIAL SURVEY OF THE UPPER KLAMATH BASIN (UKB) TO ASSESS SPATIAL AND SEASONAL PATTERNS OF AVAILABLE THIAMINE (VITAMIN B1), MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES, AND FISH TO BETTER UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL ISSUES FOR AQUATICCOMMUNITIES FOCUSED ON DISTRIBUTION OF NATIVE SUCKERS, SPECIFICALLY LOST RIVER AND SHORTNOSE SUCKER, AND REDBAND TROUT. IN ADDITION, WITH THE REMOVAL OF FOUR DAMS ON THE KLAMATH RIVER SCHEDULED FOR 2023, ANADROMOUS SALMONIDS INCLUDING CHINOOK SALMON AND STEELHEAD WILL HAVE ACCESS TO HISTORICALLY AVAILABLE HABITAT IN THE UKB. THE USFWS IS COLLABORATING WITH NOAA-NMFS AND OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU) TO CONDUCT ANALYSIS THIAMINE CYCLING WITHIN THE ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH THESE FISH LIVE, MOVE, AND FEED. THESE ANALYSES INCLUDE DETERMINATION OF THE DISSOLVED THIAMINE CONCENTRATION IN THE WATER COLUMN AND BULK SEDIMENT POREWATER IN PARALLEL WITH MICROBIAL COMMUNITY DIVERSITY ANALYSIS VIA 16S AMPLICON SEQUENCING TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE OF KNOWN THIAMINE PRODUCING/CONSUMING MICROORGANISMS IN THE ENVIRONMENT. DEVELOPING A BASELINE OF ENVIRONMENTAL THIAMINE CONCENTRATION, SHOWN TO BE A SEVERELY LIMITING VITAMIN IN OTHER SPECIES COHORT COLLAPSE EVENTS, MAY INFORM CHANGES IN HABITAT USE AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS IN THE NATIVE FISH. ADDITIONALLY, INVESTIGATING THE MICROBIAL COMMUNITY DIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT TO THE UNDERLYING MICROBIAL DRIVERS OF THIAMINE PRODUCTION IN EACH LOCALIZED ENVIRONMENT. SUCH DATA WILL PROVIDE FISHERIES AND LAND MANAGERS INFORMATION ON WHICH SPECIFIC ENVIRONMENTS HAVE ROBUST, NATURALLY OCCURRING, MICROBIAL THIAMINE SOURCES, AND THUS COULD SERVE AS STRONG CANDIDATE LOCATIONS FOR SPECIES RECOVERYEFFORTS.

A RECENT SURVEY BY MOLINA (2021) FOUND MANY STREAM REACHES (43%) HAD MODERATELY UNSTABLE TO UNSTABLE BANKS IN MCCONNELL CREEK. THE HIGH AMOUNT OF IMPERVIOUS SURFACES IN THE WATERSHED RESULTS IN EXCESSIVE STORMWATER DISCHARGE, COUPLED WITH THE LACK OF WELL ESTABLISHED RIPARIAN VEGETATION ON THE MAJORITY (56%) OF THE STREAM REACHES, LEADS TO THIS EXCESSIVE EROSION. LITTLE CAN BE DONE ABOUT REDUCING THE AMOUNT OF IMPERVIOUS SURFACES IN THE WATERSHED, BUT THE ESTABLISHMENT OF MORE DEEPLY-ROOTED VEGETATION MAY HELP MITIGATE THE STREAMBANK EROSION. THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR THE EFFECTIVENESS OF REDCEDAR REVETMENTS TO STABILIZE MCCONNELL CREEK STREAMBANKS, AND REDUCE SEDIMENTATION. THE EFFECT OF THE REVETMENTS ON AQUATIC MACROINVERTEBRATE POPULATIONS WILL ALSO BE DOCUMENTED. A WATERSHED LEVEL MAPPING OF MCCONNELL CREEK VIA GIS WILL ANALYZE THE VEGETATIVE COVER TYPES AND IMPERVIOUS SURFACES AND DRAINAGES OF THE AREA. THE DEVELOPMENT OF PERENNIAL VEGETATION WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN THE REDUCED MOWING AREAS ON BASE, RECOMMENDED BY SMITH ET AL. (2015). THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO REDUCE STREAMBANK EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION OF MCCONNELL CREEK. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1)DOCUMENT THE EROSION/DEPOSITION RATES ON STREAMBANK STABILIZATION SITES INSTALLED OVER A PERIOD OF SEVERAL YEARS DURING A PREVIOUS PROJECT; 2)CONDUCT A GIS ASSESSMENT OF THE MCCONNELL CREEK WATERSHED, MAPPING VEGETATIVE COVER TYPES, IMPERVIOUS SURFACES, AND DRAINAGE INFRASTRUCTURE. 3)MONITOR STREAM MACROINVERTEBRATE POPULATIONS FOUND ASSOCIATED WITH THE REVETMENTS OF VARYING AGES AND CONTROL SITES. 4)PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS TO ENCOURAGE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF ROBUST RIPARIAN VEGETATION. MICHAEL JUNGEN WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS BEEN CLOSELY INVOLVED WITH PLANNING THE PROJECT, AND WILL BE INVOLVED IN FIELD ACTIVITIES ON THE AIR FORCE BASE. HE WILL DISSEMINATE PROJECT RESULTS TO AFB STAKE HOLDERS.

BUILDING ON PAST, SUCCESSFUL WORK, THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO DEVELOP RESEARCH APPROACHES AT THE SCIENCE-POLICY INTERFACE. IN PARTICULAR: SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW APPROACH TO MAINSTREAMING CLIMATE CONSIDERATIONS INTO CONSERVATION PLANNING; REVIEW THE LATEST SCIENCE OF DECISION-MAKING, POLICY, AND CONSERVATION IMPLEMENTATION TO INFORM FUTURE RECOVERY, CONSERVATION, AND RESTORATION EFFORTS; INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF SPATIAL INFORMATION AT VARIOUS SCALES TO INFORM PLANNING AND DECISION MAKING; AND DEVELOP TRAINING FOR STUDENT INTERNS AND FEDERAL PARTNERS.

REHABILITATION OF LANDS USED FOR OIL AND GAS EXPLORATION AND DEVELOPMENT HAS OCCURREDACROSS THE NORTH SLOPE FOR OVER 50 YEARS. REGULATORY AGENCIES HAVE BEEN INVOLVED INGUIDING THESE REHABILITATION ACTIVITIES, BUT DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO A COMPREHENSIVEREPOSITORY OF SUBSEQUENT RESEARCH AND MONITORING REPORTS FROM REHABILITATION ACTIVITIESACROSS THE REGION. A THREE-PHASE PROJECT WOULD PROVIDE A CENTRAL REPOSITORY OFREHABILITATION RECORDS, ESTABLISH SAMPLING PROTOCOL AND PERFORM FIELD VERIFICATION OFSUCCESSFUL SITES, AND ANALYZE RESULTS TO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR REHABILITATIONACTIVITIES THAT OPTIMIZE FUNCTIONAL HABITAT AND INFORM BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.

THIS PROJECT INVOLVES PARTNERING WITH AGENCIES AND PLACER MINERS TO CO-PRODUCE, COORDINATE, AND MAINTAIN A PLACERMINING RESOURCE NETWORK TO FACILITATE INFORMATION SHARING AND UNDERSTANDING AND USE OF PRODUCTS, TOOLS, AND BESTMANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO MINIMIZE IMPACTS ON USFWS TRUST RESOURCES RELATED TO PLACER MINING OPERATIONS IN ALASKA.SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES, OUTCOMES AND PRODUCTS ARE AS FOLLOWS:OBJECTIVE 1: BUILD AND MAINTAIN A NETWORK OF AGENCY PERSONNEL, CONSULTANTS, PLACER MINERS, MINING ORGANIZATIONS,AND OTHER INTERESTED ENTITIES OR MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC.METHODS 2: CONDUCT INTERVIEWS, SURVEYS, MEETINGS AND OTHER INFORMATION GATHERING ACTIVITIES TO GATHER INPUT ANDSUGGESTIONS FOR THE PLACER MINING RESOURCE NETWORK.OUTCOME 1: ESTABLISHED NETWORK FOR COMMUNICATION AND INFORMATION/TOOLS SHARING THAT IS USEFUL AND USED BY PLACERMINERS, MINING ORGANIZATIONS, AGENCY PERSONNEL.OBJECTIVE 2: CO-DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A COMMUNICATION AND OUTREACH STRATEGY AND PRODUCTS FOR ENGAGING ANDBENEFITTING PMRN PARTICIPANTS. THE COMMUNICATION STRATEGY WILL BE BASED ON IDENTIFIED NEEDS OF PLACER MINERS ANDAGENCY PERSONNEL.METHODS 2: USING INFORMATION GATHERED FOR OBJECTIVE 1, DESIGN A COMMUNICATION STRATEGY AND PRODUCTS IDENTIFIED ASDESIRED BY PLACER MINERS AND AGENCY PERSONNEL.OUTCOME 2: COMMUNICATION STRATEGY BASED ON INPUT FROM PLACER MINERS AND AGENCY PERSONNEL. PENDING INPUT FROMPLACER MINERS AND AGENCY PERSONNEL, COMMUNICATION AND OUTREACH PRODUCTIONS COULD INCLUDE (1) AN INTERACTIVEINTERNET-BASED PLATFORM FOR PLACER MINING INFORMATION SHARING AMONG AGENCIES, MINERS, AND OTHER INTERESTEDSTAKEHOLDERS; (2) ALTERNATIVE COMMUNICATION CHANNELS AND METHODS (E.G., HARD COPY MATERIALS, PRESENTATIONS,NEWSLETTERS, IN-PERSON TRAININGS) TO REACH PLACER MINERS THAT DO NOT HAVE OR USE INTERNET-BASED OPTIONS; AND (3)TRAINING PROGRAMS.OBJECTIVE 3: PROVIDE CONTINUAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR PLACER MINERS AND AGENCIES TO PROVIDE INPUT ON AND EVALUATE THEPLACER MINING RESOURCE NETWORK.METHODS 3: DESIGN AND COORDINATE VARIOUS OPTIONS FOR INPUT GATHERING AND DIALOGUE PER THE INTERESTS OF PLACERMINERS AND AGENCY PERSONNEL. WITH INPUT FROM PARTICIPANTS, DEVELOP SPECIFIC EVALUATION CRITERIA TO ASSESS ANDIMPROVE THE PLACER MINER RESOURCE NETWORK.OUTCOME 3: USING INPUT FROM INTERVIEWS AND A SURVEY OF PLACER MINERS, PROVIDE SPECIFIC AND DIVERSE OPPORTUNITIESFOR PLACER MINERS AND AGENCY PERSONNEL TO PROVIDE INPUT TO HELP EVALUATE AND IMPROVE COMMUNICATION METHODS, TOOLSAND PRODUCTS DEVELOPED TO SERVE AND BENEFIT PARTICIPANTS IN THE NETWORK. POSSIBILITIES INCLUDE PERIODIC INPERSON/VIRTUAL MEETINGS, ON-LINE SUGGESTION BOX, PERIODIC CHECK-IN SURVEYS OR INTERVIEWS, ANALYTICS FOR ANY WEBBASEDPLATFORM THAT MAY BE DEVELOPED.

THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IS PREPARING A SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT (SSA) FOR THE ALEXANDER ARCHIPELAGO WOLF UNDER PROVISIONS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. USFWS STAFF PREPARING THE SSA INTEND TO INCLUDE TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL AND OTHER CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE CONCERNING THE WOLF POPULATION OF SOUTHEAST ALASKA FROM INDIGENOUS TLINGIT AND HAIDA SOURCES. RESEARCHERS WILL CONDUCT A LIMITED STUDY OF TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE AND OTHER CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE CONCERNING THIS WOLF POPULATION, AND PREPARE AND SUBMIT A REPORT TRANSMITTING THOSE FINDINGS.RESEARCHERS WILL CONDUCT AN ETHNOGRAPHIC LITERATURE REVIEW ABOUT THE CUSTOMARY AND TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE OF WOLVES IN TLINGIT AND HAIDA CULTURE AND HISTORY; CONSULT WITH TRIBES ABOUT THE PURPOSE AND NATURE OF THE RESEARCH AND SEEK INPUT ON TOPICS; IDENTIFY AND INTERVIEW 9-12 INDIGENOUS TLINGIT AND HAIDA EXPERTS HOLDING TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL AND CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE CONCERNING WOLVES; PREPARE TRANSCRIPTS OF THE INTERVIEWS; ANALYZE THE TRANSCRIPTS AND IDENTIFY KEY THEMES CONCERNING THE WOLF POPULATION AND THEIR POSITION IN TLINGIT AND HAIDA CULTURE AND SOCIETY; PREPARE DRAFT REPORT SYNTHESIZING THE GATHERED INFORMATION; SUBMIT DRAFT REPORT TO USFWS FOR REVIEW; REVISE AND SUBMIT FINAL REPORT TO USFWS; AND SHARE RESULTS WITH COMMUNITIES THROUGH WRITTEN MATERIALS.
THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE AND LAUNCH A NEW INDIGENOUS CONNECTIONS WEBSITE DEVELOPED TO SUPPORT PARTICIPANTS OF TRIBAL CONGRESS, EDUCATORS, LAND USE AGENCY STAFF AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE NEW MEXICO WILDLIFE FEDERATION (NMWF) IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO ASSIST WITH THE LOGISTICS FOR THE NATIVE YOUTH CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND LEADERSHIP CONGRESS (NYCALC) TO TAKE PLACE AT THE NATIONAL CONSERVATION TRAINING CENTER IN 2022.NMWF HAS PARTICIPATED IN THE NYCALC EVENT FOR SEVERAL YEARS NOW AND WOULD LIKE TO BE CONSIDERED TO AGAIN PROVIDE LOGISTICAL SUPPORT FOR THE PROGRAM. NYCALC PROVIDES INVALUABLE LEADERSHIP, STEM, AND CONSERVATION TRAINING AS WELL AS OUTDOOR SKILLS TO FUTURE NATIVE AMERICAN LEADERS. THIS PROGRAM IS VITALLY IMPORTANT BECAUSE IT ALLOWS PARTICIPANTS TO TAKE BACK THEIR LEARNINGS TO THEIR COMMUNITIES WHERE THEY CAN PROMOTE CHANGE IN CONSERVATION AND OVERCOME EVERYDAY CHALLENGES THAT ARE HAPPENING WITHIN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND. NMWF WILL ENSURE THAT PARTICIPANTS OF THIS CONGRESS HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE THIS LEARNING IN A SAFE AND ENJOYABLE ATMOSPHERE.NMWFS GOAL IS TO CREATE AN EXPERIENCE FOR 100 NATIVE AMERICAN STUDENTS THAT WILL ALLOW THEM TO FULLY ENGAGE IN THE NATIVE YOUTH COMMUNITY ADAPTATION AND LEADERSHIP CONGRESS IN A WAY THAT IS STRESS-FREE, SAFE AND CONVENIENT.WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS BY WORKING WITH THE BIA AND FWS TO DEVELOP AN AGENDA AND GOALS FOR THE CONGRESS; HELPING TO RECRUIT COMMITTED PARTICIPANTS; EDUCATING PARTICIPANTS AND MENTORS AS TO THEIR ROLE AND RESPONSIBILITIES DURING THE CONGRESS; PROVIDING LOGISTICAL SUPPORT WHILE THE STUDENTS ATTEND THE CONGRESS; AND, BE THE PRIMARY INTERFACE BETWEEN PARTICIPANTS, PARENTS, FWS AND BIA.

THIS PROJECT WILL ACCOMPLISH THREE GOALS:UPDATE TWO KEY DOCUMENTS THAT GUIDE MANAGEMENT AND DECISION-MAKING FOR PREBLE'S MEADOW JUMPING MOUSE (ZAPUS HUDSONIUS PREBLEI, PMJM) ON THE U.S. AIR FORCE ACADEMY (ACADEMY): CONSERVATION AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE ACADEMY AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLAN.IMPROVE PMJM HABITAT QUALITY ON THE ACADEMY BY INSTALLATION OF BEAVER DAM ANALOGS, AND MONITORING OF HABITAT CHANGES AND PMJM OCCURRENCE.DEVELOP AND APPLY A SCORING METHOD TO EVALUATE AND MAP RELATIVE QUALITY OF PMJM HABITATS ON THE ACADEMY.THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM (CNHP) HAS BEEN COLLABORATING ON PMJM RESEARCH WITH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS ON THE ACADEMY SINCE 1994. COLLABORATION THROUGHOUT THE PERFORMANCE PERIOD WILL INCLUDE THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE PMJM SITE CONSERVATION TEAM, CONSULTANTS ON CONCURRENT MONUMENT CREEK CORRIDOR STUDY, AND OTHER AGENCIES AND ENTITIES WHO HAVE JURISDICTION OVER PMJM HABITATS OUTSIDE THE ACADEMY (DETAILS TO BE DETERMINED IN COLLABORATION WITH ACADEMY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS).

THE NORTHEASTERN COAST OF SOUTHERN AMERICA IS ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT STOPOVER AND NON-BREEDING REGIONS FOR SHOREBIRDS IN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE.
AERIAL SURVEYS HAVE BEEN A CRUCIAL TOOL FOR GATHERING DATA ON POPULATION STATUS AND ARE THE MOST EFFECTIVE METHOD TO MONITOR SHOREBIRDS IN A REGIONS 
WHERE POPULATION ESTIMATES BASED ON MARK/RE-SIGHTING OR MARK/RECAPTURE METHODS ARE NOT ACHIEVABLE BECAUSE OF LIMITED ACCESS TO KEY SITES AND A SHORTAGE
OF OBSERVERS.  AERIAL SURVEYS CONDUCTED SINCE 2000 ALONG SOUTH AMERICA'S ATLANTIC COAST HAVE QUANTIFIED SIGNIFICANT DECLINES IN SHOREBIRD POPULATION OVER THE
30 YEARS. AERIAL SURVEYS, FOLLOWING WELL-DESCRIBED METHODS, WILL BE REPEATED IN NORTHERN AND NORTHEASTERN BRAZIL AND ALONG THE COASTS OF FRENCH GUIANA,
SURINAME, GUYANA AND COLOMBIA.  THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL SHOREBIRD POPULATION TREND AND STATUS ASSESSMENTS TO EVALUATE EFFECTIVENESS OF 
SHOREBIRD CONSERVATION ACTIONS IMPLEMENTED THROUGHOUT THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY; THE LATTER IS CRITICAL TO THE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK UNDERPINNING
THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY SHOREBIRD INITIATIVE.
COASTAL MONITORING TEAM PEA ISLAND

THE PROTECTED AREAS OF COLOMBIA ARE GROUPED INTO THE NATIONAL SYSTEM OF PROTECTED AREAS. AS OF 2018, THERE ARE 60 NATIONALLY PROTECTED 
AREAS, WHICH COVER ABOUT 169,545 KM2 AND REPRESENT MORE THAN 14% OF THE COUNTRY'S AREA. THE RESULTS OF THE ATLAS OF SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS 
ON CARIBBEAN COAST PROVED THAT THE CCC SUPPORTS MORE THAN 30,000 SHOREBIRDS (RUIZ-GUERRA ET AL. 2008) TO WHICH 5 PROTECTED AREAS ARE
CRITICALLY IMPORTANT. THE CARIBBEAN COAST OF COLOMBIA IS PART OF THE FOCAL GEOGRAPHY OF NORTHERN SOUTH AMERICA OF THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY 
SHOREBIRDS INITIATIVE (AFSI). IN THIS REGION, THERE IS A LACK OF IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT MANY SHOREBIRDS IN THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY,
INCLUDING THE LOCATIONS OF CRITICAL HABITATS AND RESOURCES THEY REQUIRE TO PERSIST THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL CYCLE, HOW THEY MOVE
ACROSS THEIR RANGES, MAJOR THREATS THEY FACE AND HOW TO MITIGATE THEM, AND THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAYS TO MEASURE POPULATION SIZES AND
DOCUMENT DEMOGRAPHIC TRENDS. THERE IS A NEED TO CONDUCT COMPREHENSIVE STUDIES TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY AREAS FOR CONSERVATION AND FILL
KNOWLEDGE GAPS ALONG THE CARIBBEAN COAST OF COLOMBIA TO CONTRIBUTE TO MEASURE CHANGES IN SHOREBIRD POPULATION ALONG THE
ATLANTIC FLYWAY. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DELIVERING WORKSHOPS TO INCREASE THE AWARENESS OF PROTECTED AREAS STAFF ABOUT THE 
CONSERVATION ISSUES FACING MIGRATORY SHOREBIRDS AND TO TRAIN THEM IN SHOREBIRD MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES, BECAUSE THE 
SUCCESSFUL IMPLEMENTATION OF THE AFSI DEPENDS ON THE PARTNERSHIP'S CAPACITY TO MONITOR CHANGE ACROSS A BROAD LANDSCAPE.

PREVIOUS INFORMATION INDICATED THAT SUBSTANTIAL HARVEST OF SHOREBIRDS WAS OCCURRING ALONG THE COAST OF GUYANA. IN THE EARLY 2000S, BAYNEY AND 
DA SILVA (2005) REPORTED A SUBSTANTIAL HARVEST OF SHOREBIRDS AND OTHER WATERBIRDS ALONG THE COAST OF GUYANA AND FOUND COMMERCIAL SELLING
OF SHOREBIRDS IN SEVERAL VILLAGES. IN 2017 AND 2018, VILLAGES BAYNEY (2005) IDENTIFIED WERE RESURVEYED AND REVEALING A SIGNIFICANT DECLINE 
IN THE NUMBER OF BEACHES WHERE SHOREBIRD HARVEST WAS OCCURRING (MOORE AND ANDRES 2019). HOWEVER, SUBSTANTIAL NUMBERS OF SHOREBIRDS WERE STILL 
BEING HARVESTED AND SOLD TO INDIVIDUALS AND IN MARKETS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE A BETTER ESTIMATE OF THE CURRENT LEVEL OF 
SHOREBIRDS HARVEST ALONG THE COAST OF GUYANA BY FOCUSING ON SITES AND MARKETS PREVIOUSLY IDENTIFIED. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE
TO THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE SHOREBIRD HARVEST IN THE CARIBBEAN AND NORTHERN SOUTH AMERICA. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES THE KEY STRATEGY IDENTIFIED 
IN THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY SHOREBIRD INITIATIVE BUSINESS PLAN (2015) OF REDUCING HUNTING PRESSURE AND ADDRESSES THE KEY ACTION TO ASSESS BIOLOGICAL 
AND SOCIAL ASPECTS OF HARVEST IDENTIFIED IN THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY SHOREBIRD INITIATIVE'S PLAN TO ADDRESS THE SUSTAINABILITY OF SHOREBIRD
HARVEST IN THE WESTERN ATLANTIC FLYWAY (ATLANTIC FLYWAY SHOREBIRD INITIATIVE HARVEST WORKING GROUP 2016).

THE ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY OF SHOREBIRDS THAT MIGRATE THROUGH OR WINTER IN TRINIDAD,AND THE LOCATION OF STAGING AND WINTERING AREAS IN THE 
COUNTRY, ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD, AND NO COMPREHENSIVE SURVEY OF SHOREBIRDS HAS BEEN CONDUCTED SINCE THE MID-1980S. RECENT WORK IDENTIFIED 
SHOREBIRD CONCENTRATION SITES IN TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO, BASED ON HISTORICAL SURVEYS, AND PROVIDED A PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF THE MAGNITUDE OF 
SHOREBIRD HUNTING. HOWEVER, THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO EXPAND THIS WORK BY CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE SEASONAL SHOREBIRD SURVEY. THE
SURVEYS WILL BUILD ON AERIAL SURVEYS CONDUCTED PREVIOUSLY AND FOCUS EFFORTS IN HIGH CONCENTRATION AREAS. OTHER SHORELINE AREAS WITH KNOWN OR
EXPECTED LOW SHOREBIRD DENSITIES WOULD BE SURVEYED IN A RANDOMIZED MANNER TO CONFIRM STATUS. INFORMATION COLLECTED AS PART OF THE PROPOSED WORK 
WILL GREATLY ASSIST THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY SHOREBIRD INITIATIVE'S (AFSI) IN UNDERSTANDING THREATS TO SHOREBIRDS IN TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO AND WORKING
TOWARD EFFECTIVE SHOREBIRD MANAGEMENT.
